_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description

The AmeriGas Spokane terminal is propane storage and distribution facility. The facility includes four

(4) above-ground storage tanks which each have a 30,000 gallon capacity. It also has two (2)

Compressors used to unload the rails cars. The terminal has a siding with one (1) rail towers designed

to hook to rail cars and unload product to storage tanks using a system of Compressors.

Compressors withdraw propane vapors from the storage tank and compress them or increase their

pressure and discharge into the rail cars to be unloaded. This process slightly decreases the

pressure in the bulk storage tanks and increases the pressure in the rail cars. As a result, liquid

propane flows from rail car to the bulk storage tanks.



The terminal has one (1) Liquid Pumps. There are two bulkheads with no meters. One bulkhead with

meter which is the main one used to load transports. Liquid propane is loaded to transports using

liquid pumps.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy



The same properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain

safety precautions in handling it to prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost, in our

operations, efforts are undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as

to minimize the risk of exposure to the surrounding communities. It is our company policy to adhere

to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. The Facility has Logistics Managers

and a Terminal Operations Supervisor who are able to immediately respond to a serious incident

and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the

incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC),

which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country. The ECC has the ability

to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any typ

e of incident encountered at

any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results



Worst Case Scenario



The worst case scenario that was considered was catastrophic release of propane from a 30, 000

Gallons Tank. Using EPA RMP Comp, the calculated worst case distance to 1 psi over pressure end

point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.4 miles



RMP Comp was used as a tool to calculate distance to endpoints of 1 psi over pressure. RMP Comp

assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario of atmospheric stability class F

(stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). Ambient air

temperature assumed is 25 C (77 F).

Alternative Release Scenario



For alternative release scenario,

 release from transfer hoses at the facility was considered. The

active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of

the hose. Using equation from Appendix C1 (EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis), the calculated

distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.02 miles
